user_message:
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of dir_reader: ```c static ssize_t dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) { DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res; if (max < 512) return 0; (void) pos; /* 'pos' is ignored as function return next one single entry per call. */ do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); if (0 >= res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; return (ssize_t) res; } ``` Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name);
explanation: All other code in the function consists of simple declarations and an explicit ignore of the unused parameter '(void) pos;', which are not candidates for unreachable-code violations. The variable declarations (DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res;) and the casting/ignoring of 'pos' do not introduce control-flow paths that could be unreachable. The loop structure and the readdir() call are legitimate runtime control flow that can terminate via the shown returns; there are no additional hidden branches or dead-code constructs outside the listed fragments. The fragments provided above are the points where control flow may make subsequent statements impossible to reach (returns after checks, results from snprintf, and the final return) and therefore warrant investigation for possible unreachable-code rule violations.
